skill.name: wp-playground
skill.description: Use for WordPress Playground workflows: fast disposable WP instances in the browser or locally via @wp-playground/cli (server, run-blueprint, build-snapshot), auto-mounting plugins/themes, switching WP/PHP versions, blueprints, and debugging (Xdebug).
skill.summary: Use for WordPress Playground workflows: fast disposable WP instances in the browser or locally via @...
skill.author: Automattic

security_audit.summary: Prompt-only documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only guidance, prompts, and references for using the legitimate @wp-playground/cli package. No file system access, network calls, or command execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Setting up WordPress locally for testing is time consuming. This skill provides instant disposable WordPress instances in your browser or via CLI. Test plugins, themes, and debug with Xdebug in isolated environments without full stack setup.
actual_capabilities: Spin up disposable WordPress instances in browser or locally
Auto-mount and test plugins and themes
Run Blueprint JSON files for scripted setup
Switch between WordPress and PHP versions
Debug with Xdebug in isolated Playground
limitations: Uses SQLite, not suitable for production databases
Not a replacement for full WordPress stack when native modules needed

use_cases.title: Test Plugins Safely
use_cases.description: Test your plugin across multiple WordPress and PHP versions without polluting your local environment.

use_cases.title: Preview Theme Changes
use_cases.description: Preview theme changes instantly in a clean WordPress environment before deploying.

use_cases.title: Reproduce Bug Reports
use_cases.description: Create reproducible WordPress environments to investigate bug reports from users.

prompt_templates.title: Quick WP Test
prompt_templates.prompt: Start a WordPress Playground instance to test a plugin. I am working in /path/to/my-plugin. Use the latest WordPress and PHP 8.3.

prompt_templates.title: Version Compatibility
prompt_templates.prompt: Test my plugin for compatibility with WordPress 6.8, 6.7, and 6.6. Use PHP 8.2. Check if the plugin activates without errors on each version.

prompt_templates.title: Blueprint Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a Blueprint to set up WordPress with my custom plugin and theme. The blueprint is at /path/to/blueprint.json. Enable Xdebug for debugging.

prompt_templates.title: Debug Session
prompt_templates.prompt: Start a WordPress Playground debugging session with Xdebug enabled. My plugin code is at /path/to/plugin. I want to step through the activation code.

output_examples.input: Start a WordPress Playground to test my plugin at /projects/my-plugin with PHP 8.2
output: Created disposable WordPress instance at http://localhost:9400

best_practices: Always verify mounted code is active by checking plugin list or theme appearance
Use Blueprints for reproducible test environments and CI validation
Never point Playground at production data since it uses ephemeral in-memory storage
anti_patterns: Do not use Playground for production database migrations
Avoid testing with real user data in disposable instances
Do not skip version compatibility testing when targeting multiple WP releases

faq.question: What versions of WordPress and PHP are supported?
faq.answer: WordPress 6.9+ and PHP 7.2.24+ are supported. PHP 8.3 is the default since July 2025.

faq.question: Can I test native PHP extensions?
faq.answer: No. Playground runs PHP in WebAssembly and cannot load native PHP extensions. Use Docker or full stack for that.

faq.question: How do I integrate with my CI pipeline?
faq.answer: Use run-blueprint command with CI-friendly outputs. Blueprints can validate plugins activate without errors.

faq.question: Is my data safe in Playground instances?
faq.answer: Playground uses ephemeral in-memory SQLite. Data is lost when the instance stops. Never use with production data.

faq.question: Why are my breakpoints not hitting in Xdebug?
faq.answer: Check IDE path mappings include the VFS path used by Playground. Confirm IDE listens on the port shown by CLI.

faq.question: How is this different from wp-env or Docker?
faq.answer: Playground runs entirely in browser or via lightweight CLI without Docker. It is faster to start but has limitations on native extensions.
